moves.2. Nf3 d6: The Philidor Defence. A fairly solid opening, although it blocks the DSB, and unnecessarily.
moves.3. d4: I follow with the usual response.
moves.4... Qe7: Defending e5. Is this a usual move?
moves.5. dxe5: I go for a trade of pawns.
moves.5... dxe5 6. Bc4: I develop my LSB, allow myself to castle and apply pressure onto f7.
moves.7. Bxe6: I decide to trade. Is this OK?
moves.7... Qxe6 8. O-O: I get my king to safety by castling.
moves.8... Bc5 9. Bg5: I develop my bishop. I guess it's OK to trade a bishop with a knight, because we both no longer have our bishop pairs.
moves.10. Bxf6 Qxf6: ?? Better would be gxf6, which reduces the threat of Qd5.
moves.11. Qd5: This forks Black's DSB and the pawn on b7. Taking b7 also lets me take the rook on a8. The best move I can see is Qc6, but even that allows Qxe5+.
moves.11... Qc6: As I expected, Black does the best move.
moves.12... Kf8 13. Rad1: Preparing to do Rd8#, if Black doesn't intervene.
moves.13... Nd7: ? Loses a bishop and knight for a rook. Better would be Be7.
moves.17. Qxe7: Faced with an overwhelming material disadvantage, Black resigns here. Feel free to comment and give constructive criticism.
